prior_works.title: Stealing Machine Learning Models via Prediction APIs
prior_works.authors: Florian Tramèr, Fan Zhang, Ari Juels, Michael K. Reiter, Thomas Ristenpart
prior_works.role: Foundational model extraction threat and query-oracle setup
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the modern model extraction threat model and metrics using black-box oracle queries, providing the baseline formulation of fidelity, query efficiency, and attacker capabilities that this paper formalizes and analyzes through competitive analysis.

prior_works.title: High Accuracy and High Fidelity Extraction of Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Matthew Jagielski, Nicholas Carlini, David Berthelot, Alex Kurakin, Nicolas Papernot
prior_works.role: Methodological benchmark for efficient, high-fidelity extraction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated practical algorithms achieving near-perfect fidelity with tight query budgets, motivating this paper’s focus on provable anytime performance and query complexity guarantees for perfect-fidelity extraction of tree-based models.

prior_works.title: Counterfactual Explanations without Opening the Black Box: Automated Decisions and the GDPR
prior_works.authors: Sandra Wachter, Brent Mittelstadt, Chris Russell
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced counterfactual explanations as a model-agnostic query primitive; this paper leverages counterfactual-style oracles to formalize how explainability signals can be harnessed for exact reconstruction of decision-tree-based predictors.

prior_works.title: Algorithmic Recourse: From Counterfactual Explanations to Interventions
prior_works.authors: Amir-Hussein Karimi, Gilles Barthe, Bernhard Schölkopf, Isabel Valera
prior_works.role: Formalization of counterfactual/recourse queries and costs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides rigorous formulations of counterfactual queries and feasibility/cost structures that inform the oracle and constraint models used to derive reconstruction guarantees and query complexity bounds in this paper.

prior_works.title: Queries and Concept Learning
prior_works.role: Theoretical basis for exact learning with membership/equivalence queries
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the classic query-learning framework (membership/equivalence/counterexample queries) that underpins the paper’s oracle-based formalization and its proofs of perfect-fidelity reconstruction via bounded queries.

prior_works.title: Learning Decision Trees Using the Fourier Spectrum
prior_works.role: Algorithmic foundations for exact decision-tree learning from queries
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows that decision trees can be exactly identified via structured queries, inspiring the paper’s tree-specific reconstruction algorithms and informing its complexity analysis for additive tree ensembles.

prior_works.title: Online Computation and Competitive Analysis
prior_works.role: Framework for competitive analysis and anytime guarantees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the competitive analysis paradigm that the paper adapts to evaluate model extraction algorithms, enabling formal competitive ratios and anytime performance guarantees for reconstruction.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—a competitive-analysis framework for oracle-based model extraction with provably perfect-fidelity reconstruction of additive decision trees—sits at the intersection of threat modeling, explainability-driven oracles, and classic query-learning theory. Tramèr et al. (2016) crystallized the black-box model extraction threat and introduced fidelity and query-efficiency metrics, which this work elevates from empirical benchmarks to formal guarantees. Jagielski et al. (2020) demonstrated that high-fidelity extraction is practically achievable under constrained queries, motivating the paper’s emphasis on anytime performance and rigorous bounds.
Counterfactual explanations, introduced by Wachter et al. (2017) and formalized further by Karimi et al. (2021), provide the specific oracle signals that make explainability a double-edged sword. By mapping counterfactual-style queries to structured constraints on decision boundaries, the paper turns explanations into informative queries for exact reconstruction.
The theoretical backbone comes from Angluin’s (1988) query-learning model and Kushilevitz and Mansour’s (1991) exact tree-learning techniques, which show how membership/counterexample-style queries can identify tree structures. Building on these insights, the paper designs reconstruction algorithms tailored to additive tree ensembles (decision trees, random forests, gradient boosting) with provable fidelity and bounded query complexity. Finally, the evaluation lens is grounded in Borodin and El-Yaniv’s (1998) competitive analysis, enabling the authors to define and prove competitive ratios and anytime guarantees for extraction procedures. Together, these works directly shape the paper’s oracle formalization, algorithmic strategy for tree reconstruction, and the novel competitive-performance framework.
